title: How to Use the ESP32 Web Flasher
description: Learn how to flash firmware to your ESP32 or ESP8266 directly from your browser using the built-in flasher tool.
author: SanjuOS Dev
content:
Guide: How to Flash your ESP32

Welcome! If you've ever wanted to put new software (firmware) on your ESP32 or ESP8266 chip but found it too complicated, you're in the right place. Our **ESP32 Web Flasher** makes it as easy as browsing a website.

### What do you need?

Before we start, make sure you have these simple things ready:
- **A Computer** with the **Google Chrome** or **Microsoft Edge** browser. Other browsers might not work yet because we need a special feature called 'Web Serial'.
- **A USB Cable** that can transfer data. (Note: some cables only charge phones and won't work for this!)
- **Your Chip** (The ESP32 or ESP8266 board).
- **The Software File** (A file ending in `.bin` that you want to put on your chip).

---

### Step 1: Plug it in
Connect your chip to your computer using the USB cable. On your SanjuOS desktop, look for the **ESP Flasher** app and click to open it.

### Step 2: Choosing the Right Speed
In the app, you'll see a setting called **Baud Rate**. Think of this as the 'talking speed' between your computer and the chip. 

> **Tip:** 115200 is the standard speed and works for almost everyone. Keep it at that unless you're an expert!

### Step 3: Connecting via the Browser
Click the big **Connect ESP32** button. A small window will pop up at the top of your browser. 

- Look for something labeled **'USB Serial Port'**, **'CP210x'**, or **'CH340'**.
- Click on it, then click **Connect**.

If you see a green 'Connected' message, you're doing great!

### Step 4: Loading your Software
Now, click on the **Upload Area** (the box with the cloud icon). Choose your `.bin` file from your computer.

Most software starts at 'Address' `0x0`. If your software guide says otherwise, you can change it, but `0x0` is usually the safest bet for beginners.

### Step 5: The Magic Part - Flashing!
Click the **Flash Firmware** button. You'll see some text scrolling at the bottomâ€”that's just the computer talking to the chip. 

```terminal
Connecting... OK
Erasing flash... OK
Writing at 0x00001000... (10%)
Writing at 0x00002000... (20%)
... 
Flash Completed Successfully!
```

Once it hits 100%, your chip will restart automatically with its new software!

![Interface Preview](/blog/flasher-interface.png)

### Questions? We're here to help!

If you run into issues, check out our [Troubleshooting Guide](https://sanju.dev/blog/esp32-troubleshooting-guide) or join our community discord. 

**Happy Building!**
